4: Microcontroller Programming

New Idea!

Part 1: I wanted to make a drawing machine, using the same circular motion used for last week's project, but control its speed and make it quite slow and predictable, with no everlasting motion. I used this code:

//MOTOR1 PINS int ena = 5; int in1 = 6; int in2 = 7; void setup() { pinMode(ena, OUTPUT); pinMode(in1, OUTPUT); pinMode(in2, OUTPUT); //CLOCKWISE MAX SPEED digitalWrite(in1,HIGH); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); analogWrite(ena, 255); delay(2000); //STOP digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); delay(2000); //COUNTERCLOCKWISE MAX SPEED digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,HIGH); analogWrite(ena, 255); delay(2000); //STOP digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); delay(2000); //CLOCKWISE HALF SPEED digitalWrite(in1,HIGH); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); analogWrite(ena, 127); delay(2000); //STOP digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); delay(2000); //COUNTERCLOCKWISE MAX SPEED digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,HIGH); analogWrite(ena, 127); delay(2000); //STOP digitalWrite(in1,LOW); digitalWrite(in2,LOW); } void loop() { }

The schematic

A simple schematic showing the following:

    1 Arduino Uno Microcontroller
    1 L298N Driver
    1 DC motor
    1 Battery Holder (5V)
    Wires

Not what I expected

I was hoping that by controling the speed without loops and in a controlled way would allow for slower drawing patterns, allowing a full circle to be draw and allowing me to move the paper around for a continous flow (since the speed would be slower and I would be able to predict the movements of the motor). However, because of the pressure applied to the pencil and the unleveled surface, only one part of the circle would be continously drawn.

The unimpressive result:

Not what I envisioned...

Moving forward:

    1. Assembly of the parts needs work to make sure all is leveled (even slight deviations will cause inbalance in the drawing).
    2. Use a hand-held controler (such as joy-stick) to avoid hardcoding movements.
    3. Maybe have multiple pencil insertions (experimentation with colors?)
    4. Consider a hand-held option?
